What appears as insignificant aspects can have huge effect: Eating lime by British sailors and the higher tensile strength of the ropes used in Brittish ships, adding a knot or two in speed, gave Great Britain a huge advantage.If the trend stays as it is, the changes global warming will greatly determine where technological focus is. Most of the worlds population is along seashores and a raid in sea level of one foot, not to mention two feet will be catastrophic; yet several feet increase can happen in several decades from now. But so will a solar flair - how many can accept that we are close to be sent back to the Stone Age because of our dependency no only on local computers but on the cloud-infrastructure?Even today, water-based infrastructures make up a huge part of the backbone of societies. The Roman empire showed what building of roads will do. Technology now allows for land-based infrastructure, a 2nd step in train-technologies. Think the silk road project. This may well be a game changer as space technology was.Lastly: Energy. There is nothing that can replace oil presently, also a limitation. As it stands, only nuclear can raise the bar but hardly with how we used it; in many aspects “idiotic.” Surely cannot go any further in space exploration with the current fuels.

Answer: AI will really take a flight once we have quantum computers with say 100 qubits at least, that have stable enough quantum coherence to do lots of useful computations. This will take more than a decade. So the coming decade will be kind of boring, gradual incremental improvements, nothing spectacular.It is probably a save bet also we won’t go to Mars this coming decade. We have the technology to do so for a long time, but nothing happened. Nobody wants it hard enough to go for it.So, the best mankind can do for the next decade is to get through it relatively unharmed.

question: https://www.quora.com/How-much-technological-and-scientific-change-will-we-witness-in-the-next-decade

Answer: What’s coming could be the most beneficial development in history, or the scariest thing we’ve ever seen… The convergence of artificial intelligence with quantum computing in a marriage I’ll callA little background…Thousands of researchers in hundreds of well-funded private and government organizations across a dozen countries are working furiously to develop quantum computers — machines that use the weird properties of the sub-atomic world to create computers that are literally millions of times more powerful than the best hardware we have today. And that’s no exaWhat’s coming could be the most beneficial development in history, or the scariest thing we’ve ever seen… The convergence of artificial intelligence with quantum computing in a marriage I’ll callA little background…Thousands of researchers in hundreds of well-funded private and government organizations across a dozen countries are working furiously to develop quantum computers — machines that use the weird properties of the sub-atomic world to create computers that are literally millions of times more powerful than the best hardware we have today. And that’s no exaggeration, viable quantum computers will literally be millions of times more potent at certain vital tasks.Quantum computing is not ready yet — it’s still in its infancy — but very serious progress is being now made. It’s advancing fast.At the same time, thousands more researchers are already making dramatic progress in artificial intelligence using recent breakthroughs in machine learning technology. Already AI can drive cars, recognize faces and diagnose medical conditions with astonishingly prescience.Artificial intelligence is also only in its childhood, but advancing very rapidly.So here’s the question…What happens when we combine the most potent AI techniques with quantum computers… what can we expect when we combine advanced machine learning with computers that are millions of times more powerful than the best we have today?The fact is, no one knows, but for the first time in technological history there is a very real chance that some sort of intelligence will emerge.It may not be independently creative like a human — or even much like a human at all — but it will certainly be able to out-think and out-plan us, able to play the game of life far better than we can.The Up Side…QI machines could be fantastically beneficial in more ways than we can count. We could ask them to work on humanity’s hardest problems and they may be able to come up with solutions no human ever though of, or even be capable of imagining.Or maybe we give the the toughest problems in mathematics and physics to solve, and maybe they can make breakthroughs all by themselves, things we can quickly put to good use.Perhaps we can even ask them to invent ever more potent generations of themselves.The convergence of AI with QC could dwarf any other technology development in human history. The possibilities are endless and the benefits could be huge.There is a down side, but it’s not what you think…Any reasonable person reading this must also ask, what happens if it goes wrong? Do we even understand what we’re doing here? It’s only natural to ask, how screwed are we if one of these things goes all psycho on us?Could it become Skynet and nuke us all? Will we see terminators ravaging the landscape? Could this lead us to a ‘rise of the machines’, completely out of control and bent on killing us?The answer is a resounding NO.You see, their very brilliance is what also makes quantum computers pathetically easy to kill… a single bullet penetrating the quantum isolation chamber will stop a QI in it’s tracks, stone cold dead. Permanently.Rogue machines aren’t a risk, instead the problem is with rogue people and nations, as usual.Quantum Wars…It’s easy to guess that the military of advanced nations like the USA, Russia, China, South Korea, Japan and members of the EU will be early and enthusiastic adopters of QI, once the money they are already pouring into research bears fruit.So the real threat isn’t a single Skynet-like machine going berserk, the danger is we get into a sort of quantumThat is what AI might be like 30 years from now.

Jeff Williams … hails ‘neural engines’ in its iPhones and watches before pre-orders of iPhone X embedded with AI features.What got me thinking about paradigm shifts here isn’t the AI engine, but the sales figures for the iPhone 8 & X models. Apple was reportedly expecting a 50/50 split in saI have a spider-sense for paradigm shifts, and there are a few big ones going on right now. Here’s one that just caught my eye -Apple sees its mobile devices as a major platform for artificial intelligence in the future, the company’s chief operating officer Jeff Williams said on Monday. Jeff Williams … hails ‘neural engines’ in its iPhones and watches before pre-orders of iPhone X embedded with AI features.What got me thinking about paradigm shifts here isn’t the AI engine, but the sales figures for the iPhone 8 & X models. Apple was reportedly expecting a 50/50 split in sales between the two models. Instead, the iPhone 8 sold so poorly Apple had toThat tells me the market is looking for something new & innovative, and is willing to spend big money for it. It’s likely telling Apple they have a green light to develop more expensive & elaborate features as well.Is artificial intelligence that feature? Jeff Williams said their goal was to focus primarily on “general AI”, but Apple has left the development of these new apps up to developers. Will we see smartphones start to become a lot smarter, a lot faster?If so, it may take a while. Five years is a reasonable timeframe for Apple’s A11 neural chip to become standard, and Samsung & competitors to deploy their own version of it. However, it doesn’t mean that we won’t start seeing a completely new type of

There are doctors and IIT and Engineering students in hundreds and thousands who don't get suitable placement in TamilNadu. One of my three girl cousins a CEO of an international IT company. Other one is a principal in a popular college the third one is a senior scientist (automic energy ) all of them have obtained doctorates in their respective fields My daughter is a doctor. Many of my nieces and nephews are doctors and Engineers working in USA and other major countries. Except my children all are away from India. My children are not well paid though they are well qualified. They prefered to live in India as their spouses are placed in India.In Bangalore Tamils are the majority employees in IT companies. Kannadigas are the minority in this sector.Tamils are now particular about their ancient past. They believe in their rich çulture and literature. They still believe in hard work, agriculture and small business enterprises.The Corporate companies are patronized by most corrupt politicians in power. They loot national wealth. Probably they are sharing it with politicians. Otherwise how could they get ports, sea shores, mountains, forests, mines, aviation, shipping , banking, insurance, even defense manufacturing under their control. It was happening only in Madurai. Now it is happening everywhere. It is now taken over by politicians. Previously the BJP tried to hurt Tamils by removing Pongal holidays for central government employees in the state and tried to ban Jalli Kattu. It was seen as suppression of culture and rights of the people. Hence Jalli Kattu protest took place. BJP lost a chance of winning the Tamils’ support. I think they are not bothered.In the past the winners in Jalli Kattu were given preference to find better life partners. It was considered as bravery/valor. It was an ancient culture.Personally I do not patronize Jalli Kattu for men are injured and they lose their lives too. If they could conduct it with more protection I think there shouldn't be any concern. It is part of rural celebrations.If you are really concerned for the state and Tamils support the farming communities. India is an agrarian country. Agriculture is also a noble profession.My uncles are educated farmers.Thank you very much for your interest in the welfare of the state.

Answer: I won’t be here to see it, but pilotless airliners are a possibility. That leads to pilotless heavy military transport aircraft. The military will also be using pilotless refueling aircraft & pilotless sovereignty-patrol aircraft.Don’t get excited about the likelihood of pilotless strike-fighters in that period, or pilotless close support platforms — it won’t happen that quickly in those roles.The next fighter will be manned, as will close-support aircraft.Engine technology will continue apace, with increased output & ever better fuel economy — but it will be evolutionary rather than revolutioI won’t be here to see it, but pilotless airliners are a possibility. That leads to pilotless heavy military transport aircraft. The military will also be using pilotless refueling aircraft & pilotless sovereignty-patrol aircraft.Don’t get excited about the likelihood of pilotless strike-fighters in that period, or pilotless close support platforms — it won’t happen that quickly in those roles.The next fighter will be manned, as will close-support aircraft.Engine technology will continue apace, with increased output & ever better fuel economy — but it will be evolutionary rather than revolutionary. Synthetic fuels will be viable & in quantity by then.There will not be electrically powered heavy aircraft of any description & lighter than-air vehicles will not make a resurgence, other than as flying construction cranes or very slow, short-ranged heavy lift vehicles.That’s my guess for the next 20–30 yrs.

Answer: You’re asking for a prediction. I won’t give you an answer, but I will say that we are in complete command of the ability to make our fate either way or any of the many ways in between. Those who survive will progress and will consider themselves to be advancing.It would be nice if the challenges we face were harder on those less able to deal with them, but coronavirus makes the point that it isn’t always the fittest who survive, or at least not fit the way we measure it.It seems to me that the people who are most valuable are those who are actively working to promote the solutions, rather thaYou’re asking for a prediction. I won’t give you an answer, but I will say that we are in complete command of the ability to make our fate either way or any of the many ways in between. Those who survive will progress and will consider themselves to be advancing.It would be nice if the challenges we face were harder on those less able to deal with them, but coronavirus makes the point that it isn’t always the fittest who survive, or at least not fit the way we measure it.It seems to me that the people who are most valuable are those who are actively working to promote the solutions, rather than just hoping someone else will take care of it for them. No one can do everything, but you get a sense of satisfaction from doing one thing well.One thing I think we really need to try to do better is to frame our questions. Quora is a perfect example of how easy it is to ask a question badly. If you read answers “similar” to the one you ask, you may find that the question can be stated more clearly, or that it has already been answered. I’m not ready to advocate for changing Quora, but it might be possible to make it harder to ask a duplicative question without reading some of the previous answers. On the other hand, allowing people to ask their own question has its own value.One other thing we absolutely need to try to do better is be more respectful. I see a lot of questions evoke rude responses when it is clear to me that the problem with the question is due to the questioner having to write in a second language. I love the international quality of this website, even as I wish that people had to identify their locale when they ask questions.

Answer: There is far more danger that some set of circumstances could send us into a “bitopia” or highly divided class of wealthy, technical class and administrative class and then a large group of “others”. What that “other” class looks like is the big unanswered question. Ideally it could be a pool from which the talented rise into one of the alternate groups and the remainder live a mostly comfortable life of “bread and circuses” or the modern equivalent of TV, sports and internet with a UBI for food and housing. Worst case it becomes a place of crime, exploitation and despair.Technology today is wThere is far more danger that some set of circumstances could send us into a “bitopia” or highly divided class of wealthy, technical class and administrative class and then a large group of “others”. What that “other” class looks like is the big unanswered question. Ideally it could be a pool from which the talented rise into one of the alternate groups and the remainder live a mostly comfortable life of “bread and circuses” or the modern equivalent of TV, sports and internet with a UBI for food and housing. Worst case it becomes a place of crime, exploitation and despair.Technology today is widespread enough, literacy is common enough that it is highly unlikely that any single calamity can “reset” humanity. Anything is possible, but it is improbable for humanity to be drastically set back far enough to make recovery impossible short of an actual planet destruction scenario.
